title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
US intelligence has concluded Russia's president Vladimir Putin authorised “influence operations” aimed at supporting Donald Trump's bid for re-election in the 2020 presidential campaign.

The assessment from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which oversees 18 US intelligence agencies, found that the Kremlin stopped short of backing the kinds of hacking missions carried out in 2016, which included attempts to break into “election infrastructure”.

Instead, Putin focused on disinformation campaigns aimed at undermining Joe Biden's candidacy and American confidence in the election process. (FT)

Coronavirus digest

  • Americans are expected to pour billions of dollars into the stock market when stimulus payments begin hitting bank accounts this week. Despite receiving little of Joe Biden's $1.9tn Covid-19 relief package, big business is set to benefit from the “trickle down” model of support.

  • The EU drugs regulator has reiterated that the benefits of the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine outweighed the risks. The EU is to propose the creation of a Covid-19 certificate to allow citizens to travel inside the bloc.

  • More than half of UK managers want to be allowed to make vaccinations mandatory for staff returning to work, according to a survey.

  • China will accept travellers from the Philippines, Indonesia and elsewhere — if they have received Chinese-made vaccines. (FT, Straits Times)

The AstraZeneca debacle shows how a public relations triumph can, if handled badly, turn out to be a trap, writes Brooke Masters. The FT View is that authorities must maintain public confidence while avoiding overreaction to side-effects that are not really a result of vaccinations.

Follow our live blog for the latest

In the news

US targets officials for undermining territory's autonomy The Biden administration has accused two dozen Chinese and Hong Kong officials of undermining autonomy in the territory. The move subjected the officials to sanctions under the Hong Kong Autonomy Act, which was introduced by the previous US administration. (FT)

Atlanta shootings fuel concern over violence against Asian-Americans A 21-year-old man has been arrested in connection with the shooting dead of at least eight people at a massage parlour and two spas in the Atlanta area. Police said the attacks appeared to be co-ordinated and described six of the eight victims as Asian women or women of Asian descent. (FT)

Biden says Cuomo should quit if inquiry confirms allegations New York governor Andrew Cuomo should resign if investigations confirm allegations that he committed sexual harassment, US president Joe Biden has said. Biden's position, articulated in a television interview with ABC News, was the first time the Democratic president has waded into the crisis engulfing Cuomo, a friend and political ally. (FT)

Uber agrees to classify UK drivers as workers The ride-hailing company will reclassify its roughly 7,000 UK drivers as workers, falling partly in line with a Supreme Court ruling, but probably setting up another round of disputes over what should be considered “working time” in the gig economy. (FT)

Greensill family cashed out $200m before collapse Lex Greensill and his family sold about $200m of shares in Greensill Capital in 2019, cashing out during a fundraising round led by SoftBank's Vision Fund two years before the company collapsed, three people with knowledge of the matter said. (FT)

Review sets out ‘Global Britain's' balancing act In the first review of the UK's security, defence and foreign policy since the country ended its five-decade membership of the European Union, Boris Johnson promised to make Britain “match-fit for a more competitive world”. (FT)

Vehicle chargers follow Wall Street buzz to plug into Spacs Big plans to build more battery-powered cars have led the companies that charge them to Wall Street in a fusion of two buzzy trends: the electric vehicle and the special purpose acquisition company.

  • Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, is considering making electric vehicles at its plant in Wisconsin as soon as 2023 as it seeks to reduce its dependence on Apple. (FT)

Court says Japan's ban on same-sex marriage is ‘unconstitutional'
The Sapporo district court ruled that preventing three same-sex couples from marrying violated Article 14 of Japan's constitution, which outlaws discrimination on grounds of race, creed, sex, social status or family origin. (FT)

Myanmar's deadly violence Security forces killed at least two protesters on Tuesday after a weekend of violence, with dozens of deaths in a factory zone in Yangon. Businesspeople warned that the turmoil was threatening to wipe out a decade of economic gains. (AP, FT)

The day ahead

US wades into Northern Ireland impasse Joe Biden will hold St Patrick's day talks with Irish premier Micheál Martin as lawmakers in Washington put pressure on Boris Johnson's government to end its stand-off with the EU. (FT)

Central banks The Federal Reserve is poised to upgrade its forecasts for the US economy on Wednesday, pointing to an accelerated pandemic recovery. Brazil's central bank also meets and is expected to raise rates for the first time since 2015. (FT)

Vaccine testimony Dr Anthony Fauci, chief medical adviser to Joe Biden, and Rochelle Walensky, the director of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, will answer lawmakers' questions on the US vaccine programme. (FT)

US officials in South Korea Antony Blinken, secretary of state, and Lloyd Austin, defence secretary, are in Seoul amid warnings from North Korea against holding joint military drills. (FT)

What else we're reading

New battle lines: voting rights With the stimulus bill passed, Democrats in Washington are now turning their attention to voting rights. They are targeting the restoration of the Voting Rights Act, a key piece of federal civil rights legislation from 1965 that was partly dismantled by the US Supreme Court in 2013. (FT)

America's progressive revolution is not here yet America's social democratic turn has been in the works for decades but today's progressive moment is not quite as resounding as currently billed, writes Janan Ganesh.

Economies can survive a stock market crash A stock market correction is possible as Covid-19 comes under control, economies normalise and interest rates rise, writes Martin Wolf. But this, in itself, is not something to worry much about — far more serious would be a debt crisis that damages core institutions, freezes markets and creates mass bankruptcies.

How Stripe became Silicon Valley's most prized asset The most prominent start-ups are normally consumer internet ventures such as Facebook and Uber. Yet Stripe, a name unfamiliar to most tech outsiders, sits atop the list of most prized private companies after investors valued it at $95bn. How did the low-profile payments group do it? (FT)

Danone chief's fall from favour Emmanuel Faber's seven-year reign at Danone ended around 1:30am on Monday. His ousting after a marathon board meeting was a victory for activist funds that have laid siege to the French consumer goods group, alleging chronic underperformance. But it marked a loss for those who prized the 57-year-old as a powerful advocate for pursuing sustainability alongside profit. (FT)

London's Met police force faces its MeToo moment The kidnap and murder of Sarah Everard has provoked outrage from women across the UK, who are demanding better protection from the country's criminal justice system and police. In London, where Everard lived, the Metropolitan police force is facing its MeToo moment. (FT)

Podcast of the day

What happened next: The jeweller redesigning her business Consumer editor Claer Barrett catches up with 30-year-old jewellery designer Roseanna Croft. When they last spoke in October her small business was reeling from the impact of coronavirus. Money Clinic experts advised Roseanna on accessing financial support, and finding a new direction for her business under lockdown. Five months on, has she managed to resolve her financial issues? (FT)
